title.value: Casting Light on Large Generative Networks: Taming Epistemic Uncertainty in Diffusion Models
title.justification: Extracted from the first pages of the document where the paper title is stated.
title.quote: CASTING LIGHT ON LARGE GENERATIVE NETWORKS: TAMING EPISTEMIC UNCERTAINTY IN DIFFUSION MODELS

extractions.description: This paper introduces an innovative framework, diffusion ensembles for capturing uncertainty (DECU), aimed at estimating epistemic uncertainty in large high-performing generative diffusion models, which generate high-dimensional images. The framework achieves computational efficiency by training ensembles within conditional networks using a static set of pre-trained parameters, significantly reducing the computational load. Pairwise-Distance Estimators (PaiDEs) are employed to capture epistemic uncertainty. Experiments validate the effectiveness of DECU on the Imagenet dataset, marking an advancement in detecting epistemic uncertainty in these models.

type.justification: The paper involves experiments and evaluates the proposed framework's capability to estimate epistemic uncertainty in diffusion models using the Imagenet dataset, which characterizes it as an empirical study.
type.quote: To validate the effectiveness of our framework, we conducted experiments on the Imagenet dataset.

name.justification: The paper primarily addresses uncertainty estimation (specifically epistemic uncertainty) in generative diffusion models.
name.quote: This study represents a significant advancement in detecting epistemic uncertainty for conditional diffusion models.

name.justification: The study involves high-dimensional image generation and evaluation, which falls under the scope of computer vision.
name.quote: These models typically encompass over 100 million parameters and generate outputs within a high-dimensional image space.

name.justification: DECU is explicitly named as the innovative framework introduced by this paper for estimating epistemic uncertainty in diffusion models.
name.quote: In this work, we introduce an innovative framework, diffusion ensembles for capturing uncertainty (DECU), designed for estimating epistemic uncertainty within the realm of large high-performing generative diffusion models.

is_contributed.justification: DECU is the novel method introduced by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: In this work, we introduce an innovative framework, diffusion ensembles for capturing uncertainty (DECU)

is_executed.justification: The paper describes the execution of DECU on the Imagenet dataset.
is_executed.quote: To validate the effectiveness of our framework, we conducted experiments on the Imagenet dataset.

is_compared.justification: There is no mention of numerical comparison of DECU with other models; the paper focuses on its implementation and validation within its context.
is_compared.quote: We evaluate DECU on the Imagenet dataset, and our contributions can be summarized as follows...

referenced_paper_title.justification: DECU is a novel contribution from this paper itself, so there is no referenced paper for it.

name.justification: Imagenet is explicitly named as the dataset used for experiments in this paper.
name.quote: We evaluate DECU on the Imagenet dataset Russakovsky et al. (2015), and our contributions can be summarized as follows

referenced_paper_title.value: Imagenet Large Scale Visual Recognition Challenge
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for Imagenet is clearly mentioned in the bibliography section.

name.justification: The paper indicates the use of a library for deep learning purposes.
name.quote: Please refer to the codebase available at (https://github.com/CompVis/latent-diffusion), making specific modifications to incorporate DECU.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references the use of PyTorch but does not cite a specific paper for it.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Please refer to the codebase available at (https://github.com/CompVis/latent-diffusion), making specific modifications to incorporate DECU.
